Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of Broadcom's VMware licensing changes and their impact on SMB customers in late 2025:

## Key Licensing Changes

### Shift to Subscription Model
Broadcom no longer sells VMware perpetual licenses, with the company moving instead to a subscription-based model. Existing perpetual licenses remain valid, but support services cannot be renewed unless a pre-existing contract is in place.

### Core Minimum Requirements
All VMware products now require a minimum of 72 cores per purchase or license ‚Äì up from the previous minimum of 16 cores. This will force smaller organizations with modest IT infrastructures to pay for significantly more cores than they need.

However, there's conflicting information: After swift backlash from customers and partners ‚Äì who pointed out this would punish small deployments and lab setups ‚Äì Broadcom quietly retracted the 72-core minimum policy. As of now, the 16-core-per-CPU rule still applies, but there is no 72-core minimum order.

### Product Changes
Broadcom has retired the Essentials Plus Kit and reintroduced Enterprise Plus. All licensing is now per-core with a 16-core minimum per CPU, affecting cost and flexibility for many organizations.

### Partner Ecosystem Reduction
In April 2025, Broadcom reduced the number of authorized VMware Cloud Service Providers (VCSPs) from over 4,500 globally to a much smaller number ‚Äì including only 12 Pinnacle partners and 300+ Premier partners in the US. July 2025 brought further reductions (down to 13 VCSPs), along with a rebranded program.(no content)October 31, 2025 will mark the end of the White Label model, which allowed smaller VCSPs (those consuming less than 3,500 cores) to purchase licenses through higher-level Pinnacle or Premier partners.

## SMB Customer Impact

### Disproportionate Cost Increases
Small and mid-sized businesses (SMBs) are among the most severely affected. Many entry-level bundles (like VMware's Essentials kits) have been discontinued, and new licensing minimums force even modest environments to pay for more capacity than they use. As a result, some SMBs have seen annual VMware costs double, triple, or even increase tenfold.(no content)Industry reports indicate price hikes ranging from 150% to 1,200% for customers transitioning from perpetual or standalone licenses. For example, a UK university reported a 1,250% increase, with its annual support cost rising from ¬£40,000 to ¬£500,000 under the new VCF bundle mandate.

### Late Renewal Penalties
That's a big cost jump for SMBs and edge deployments. Late renewals now come with a 20% penalty if you miss your renewal window.

### Strategic Focus Away from SMBs
Organizations running smaller VMware setups will experience higher ongoing costs, stricter renewal terms, and reduced flexibility. Broadcom appears focused on larger enterprise customers, leaving smaller customers with a difficult choice: pay significantly more, find creative workarounds, or consider alternative platforms.

## Recommendations for SMBs

Audit your real needs ‚Äì Most SMBs don't need features like DRS or Distributed Switching. Budget now ‚Äì Pricing is going up. Plan before renewals hit. Consider alternative hypervisors or cloud-native options if pricing is prohibitive.(no content)Some customers‚Äîparticularly SMBs‚Äîmay find the new economics untenable. Others will stay the course but need a sharper plan to right-size core consumption, rationalize features, and negotiate terms that fit budget cycles.

## Key Pricing Changes

Broadcom's VMware license pricing changes, announced in December 2023 and refined through 2025, replace perpetual licenses with subscriptions, introduce a 72-core minimum, and enforce bundled purchases, significantly altering cost structures.

### Subscription Model & Price Increases
- VMware's licensing model underwent a seismic shift in 2025 after Broadcom acquired VMware. Broadcom moved quickly to end perpetual licenses in favor of subscriptions, aiming to generate steady recurring revenue. The old one-time purchase + annual support model is gone, replaced by "renting" software year by year.

- The numbers are staggering. Some customers report price increases ranging from 800% to 1,500%, while some organizations face even more dramatic hikes. AT&T claimed Broadcom offered them a 1,050% price increase, transforming their annual VMware costs from manageable to prohibitive overnight.

### 72-Core Minimum Requirement
- Starting April 10, 2025, VMware will enforce a minimum 72-core license subscription for products like vSphere Standard, up from the previous 16-core minimum. This change disproportionately affects SMBs and organizations with smaller CPU footprints, such as those operating edge locations or remote offices. The increased core requirement effectively raises costs, as customers must pay for licenses that may exceed their actual needs.

### Product Consolidation
- Broadcom has consolidated VMware's extensive product portfolio, reducing the number of stock-keeping units (SKUs) from approximately 8,000 to a few bundled offerings, primarily VMware Cloud Foundation (VCF) and vSphere Foundation (VVF). While this simplifies the product structure, it forces customers to purchase bundled products like NSX Networking and vSAN, even if they don't need them. This lack of flexibility has led to higher costs for organizations that previously purchased standalone products.

### 50% VCF Price Reduction (With Caveats)
- Broadcom has publicized a 50% price reduction for VMware Cloud Foundation, dropping the per-core annual subscription fee from $700 to $350. However, this reduction is offset by the bundled structure and the removal of standalone product options, meaning many customers still face net cost increases. Additionally, the base pricing from which this reduction is calculated remains unclear, raising questions about the actual savings.

### Partner Ecosystem Reduction
- In April 2025, Broadcom reduced the number of authorized VMware Cloud Service Providers (VCSPs) from over 4,500 globally to a much smaller number ‚Äì including only 12 Pinnacle partners and 300+ Premier partners in the US. July 2025 brought further reductions (down to 13 VCSPs), along with a rebranded program (the "VMware Advantage Partners VCSP program"). Partners who were not invited to the new program can only transact until October 31, 2025.

### November 2025 Hyperscaler Changes
- Effective November 1, 2025, customers using Azure VMware Solution or similar services must procure portable VCF subscriptions directly from Broadcom, discontinuing bundled licensing through hyperscalers post-October 15, 2025.

### Support Cost Increases
- VMware's support and subscription (SnS) fees have historically been around 22% of the license price annually for maintenance and updates. Post-acquisition, Broadcom is pushing support fees into the 25%‚Äì30% range of the license value. In other words, if you spend $1 million on VMware licenses, you might pay up to $300k each year just to receive support and software updates (whereas previously it may have been approximately $220k).

### Additional Penalties
- Broadcom has introduced a 20% penalty on the first-year subscription price for customers who fail to renew their subscriptions by the anniversary date. This policy adds financial pressure on organizations to renew promptly.

- VMware is moving away from annual renewals, requiring customers to commit to three- or five-year subscription terms. This change limits flexibility and locks organizations into long-term agreements.

### VMware Explore 2025 Update
VMware demonstrated that VCF 9.0 is here, now with Kubernetes and Data Services capabilities baked in. Broadcom announced VCF 9.0 last year at Explore, and the platform update went live in June of 2025.(no content)VMware has a clear and simple message: "Meet with your rep and go through your situation." VMware's new pricing and packaging strategy has major implications for its clients. VMware's strategy pushes them to either go all in or look elsewhere ‚Äî for clients and partners alike.

MSIG was also a Nutanix user and has now moved its entire fleet of 1,500 to 2,000 Nutanix virtual machines. Golding moved to Nutanix too, adopting NC2 clusters in AWS.(no content)Johnston told The Register the migration process was simple, and that he was even able to stay hands-off over the weekend when it took place.

### US Navy & Moody's ‚Üí Nutanix
The Register met Johnston and Kee at Nutanix's Next conference this week, where the US Navy and financial services company Moody's recounted their VMware migrations. Nutanix CEO Rajiv Ramaswami told The Register that Nutanix was only able to win Moody's after deciding to change its tune and start supporting external storage.

### HorizonIQ ‚Üí Proxmox
Learn how HorizonIQ replaced VMware with Proxmox VE, reducing costs by 94% while improving scalability, management, and infrastructure control.

## Market Landscape

Red Hat and HPE have both created server virtualization products, Citrix has re-entered the market, smaller HCI players like Scale Computing are frisky, and open source projects like XCP-NG and Proxmox are on the march.(no content)Proxmox VE has gained tremendous ground across many different verticals over the past couple of years. It started out as a home lab favorite. However, it has now started to gain ground in the enterprise due to the totally free and open source model and intuitive interface.(no content)Nutanix has seen exponential growth since the Broadcom acquisition of VMware.

## Platform Comparisons

XCP-ng is the most analogous to ESXi and vCenter and is free.(no content)Proxmox VE is a feature-rich virtualization platform that combines KVM and LXC containers, offering enterprise capabilities like clustering, live migration, and backup‚Äîwithout licensing fees.(no content)Nutanix's AHV hypervisor comes bundled with its Hyper-Converged Infrastructure (HCI) platform. It simplifies operations with a single pane of glass, integrates backup/DR natively, and is designed for hybrid and multi-cloud environments. AHV is gaining traction as a stable ESXi alternative without separate licensing costs.

## Migration Guidance

Smart organizations are adopting incremental approaches rather than big-bang migrations. This strategy includes pilot projects with non-critical workloads and skills development on chosen platforms in a lab environment.(no content)One thing is clear: 2025 is not the year to delay. With licensing and support models changing fast, IT leaders need to evaluate, pilot, and chart a migration roadmap now to avoid unexpected costs and disruptions later.
